head.supplied: 26/9/65 ¶ ¶ I intended, dear Sir William, to have sent you my departmental Report by this mail & the 34 No of the Fragmenta. ¶ Of both I have proof but they are not ready for this mail. By next mail...

div.p: RBG Kew, Directors' letters, vol. LXXV, Australian and Pacific letters 1859-65, letter no. 196.

I intended, dear Sir William, to have sent you my departmental Report by this mail & the 34 No of the Fragmenta.
B65.10.01, B65.10.04. Of both I have proof but they are not ready for this mail. By next mail I shall have some plates again to send. The enclosed seed would be worth particular attention. The spinage is really excellent.
Nothing has been done respecting Prof Lindleys library. I believe the best plan would be to adress his Excellency Sir Charl Darling through Mr Cardwell on the subject.

I wished I could secure the herbarium too. If so I should possess one of the most extensive & important collections of dry plants anywhere.
See M to W. Hooker, 20 August 1865, and M to W. Hooker, 25 August 1865 (in this edition as 65-08-25a). Hooker died on 12 August, before these letters were written. See Lucas (2008).

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p: Could your noble garden spare me a plant in a Wardian Case of Ficus Sycamorus? This tree is a favorite for shading roadsides in Egypt & we should have the tree finally all over Australia.
